com.pixolus.meterreading

Class MeterReadingFragment

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.app.Fragment
      • com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ComponentCallbacks, ComponentCallbacks2, View.OnCreateContextMenuListener

    public class MeterReadingFragment
extends Fragment
    Self-contained Fragment to perform optical meter and barcode reading.

    Integrate a meter reading fragment in your layout by placing it in the layout XML file or instantiate a new instance and use the FragmentManager of your activity to add it to the view hierarchy. Your Activity needs to implement the CameraListener interface and either the MeterReadingListener and/or BarcodeReadingListener, because this Fragment expects to pass results by callback.

    You can place the fragment anywhere in your Layout. It will present a live camera view and process the video data to find and read meters and/or barcodes. After camera initialization, it will call CameraListener.onCameraReady(MeterReadingFragment) in your activity.

    When your Activity implements the MeterReadingListener interface, as soon as results are found, they will be reported by calling onScanReadings() passing a list of MeterReadingResult instances, a Bitmap and metadata.

    In case your Activity implements the BarcodeReadingListener interface, scanned barcodes will be reported by calling onScanBarcodes() passing a list of BarcodeReadingResult instances, a Bitmap and metadata.

    The MeterReadingFragment will carry on processing video after results were found, so the onScanReadings and onScanBarcodes callback may be invoked multiple times unless you destroy the fragment, set setNumberOfCounters(int) to 0 or set setBarcodeFormats(ArrayList) to an empty list.

    When the fragment is re-instantiated during state restore (e.g. due to an orientation change of the device) and the camera device's torch/flashlight was on, it will be shortly switched off and then on again. This is expected behavior.

    Note that because the camera hardware is an exclusive resource, you need to make sure that only a single instance of the MeterReadingFragment exists at any time within your app, otherwise an alert dialog will be displayed, warning that the camera could not be accessed. Fragments in an activity are automatically re-instantiated during state restore (e.g. orientation change of the device). So if you manually instantiate a MeterReadingFragment (e.g. in your activity's Activity.onCreate(android.os.Bundle) method) you should first check with the FragmentManager of the activity whether your instance has already been re-instantiated. In case your activity is not restarted on device rotation, i.e. you handle configuration changes in your activity's Activity.onConfigurationChanged(android.content.res.Configuration) method, do not forget to also call onConfigurationChanged(android.content.res.Configuration).

    Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter and barcode reading for your application scenario.

      void setBarcodeCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation barcodeCaptureAnimation)
      Deprecated. 
      Please use setBarcodeCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) instead.

      If you plan to verify detected barcode results in your implementation of the BarcodeReadingListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) method, you might want to decide when to show the capture animation. You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

      Default animation: MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation.NONE

    • Field Detail

      • AUTOMATIC

        public static final int AUTOMATIC
        Constant indicating unknown or arbitrary number of digits and counters.

        This constant can be used for integerDigits, fractionDigits, and numberOfCounters. In general, choosing automatic mode makes detection more flexible but bears a risk that a result is returned although not all information is visible (yet). For example, part of a counter may be hidden behind a reflection on the cover glass while the other part is well legible. The detection can only return the visible part.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        See Also:
        setIntegerDigits(int), setFractionDigits(int), setNumberOfCounters(int), Constant Field Values

      • INVALID

        public static final int INVALID
        Constant invalidating a configuration.

        This is the default value for integerDigits, fractionDigits, and numberOfCounters. If one of these properties is set to INVALID, a warning message is shown in the camera preview about the invalid configuration and no meters will be read.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        See Also:
        setIntegerDigits(int), setFractionDigits(int), setNumberOfCounters(int), Constant Field Values

      • setIntegerDigits

        public void setIntegerDigits(int integerDigits)
        The number of integer digits present on the meter to be read by the receiver.

        Allowed values are 1, ..., 12 and AUTOMATIC.

        The default value is INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:
        integerDigits - Either the number of integer digits on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • getIntegerDigits

        public int getIntegerDigits()
        Return the number of integer digits present on the meter to be read by the receiver.
        Returns:
        Either the number of integer digits on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

        public void setFractionDigits(int fractionDigits)

        Allowed values are 0, ..., 8 and AUTOMATIC.

        The default value is INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:

      • setNumberOfCounters

        public void setNumberOfCounters(int numberOfCounters)
        The number of counters present on the meter to be read by the receiver.

        Allowed values are 0, ..., 2 and AUTOMATIC.

        You may set this value to 0, in which case the MeterReadingListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) callback is never called.

        The default value is INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:
        numberOfCounters - Either the number of counters on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • getNumberOfCounters

        public int getNumberOfCounters()
        Return the number of counters present on the meter to be read by the receiver.
        Returns:
        Either the number of counters on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:

        public void setTimeout(double timeout)
        Set timeout value.

        The time (in seconds) after which the receiver automatically captures an image after the receiver has started processing. (Only if greater than 0.) Default value is 0.

        Parameters:
        timeout - The timeout value in seconds.

      • setTimeoutUnreadableCounter

        public void setTimeoutUnreadableCounter(double timeoutUnreadableCounter)
        Set timeout value for when a counter was detected but could not be read.

        The time (in seconds) after which the receiver automatically captures an image if a meter could be detected but no OCR is possible for the specified amount of time. (Only if greater than 0.) Default value is 0.

        Parameters:
        timeoutUnreadableCounter - The timeout value in seconds.

      • setTimeoutAfterLastDetection

        public void setTimeoutAfterLastDetection(double timeoutAfterLastDetection)
        Set timeout value for when a counter was detected at least once but no detection occurred for a certain period.

        The time (in seconds) after which the receiver automatically captures an image if no meter could be detected for the specified amount of time. (Only if greater than 0.) Default value is 0.

        Parameters:
        timeoutAfterLastDetection - The timeout value in seconds.

      • setZoom

        public void setZoom(double zoom)
        Set the magnification factor used for camera preview. Default value is 1.

        A magnification factor of 1 means that the visible portion of the preview is maximized under the condition that the whole area of the fragment is covered by the preview. This means that if the preview video has a different aspect ratio than the fragment, the preview is scaled proportionally such that either the width of the preview matches the width of the fragment (cropping top and bottom parts of the preview) or the height of the preview matches the height of the fragment (cropping left and right parts of the preview) but never both. The preview is always centered within the fragment.

        When the magnification factor is larger than 1, the preview is scaled proportionally from the center of the fragment/preview. As a consequence all four edges of the preview will be cropped.

        Note that while this setting affects the scaling of the camera preview, it has no effect on the image supplied via the MeterReadingListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) callback.

        Also note that the fragment only reads meters/counters which are within the visible area of the preview.

        Parameters:
        zoom - The magnification factor.

      • getZoom

        public double getZoom()
        Return the magnification factor used for camera preview.
        Returns:
        The magnification factor.
        See Also:
        setZoom(double)

      • setBarcodeFormats

        public void setBarcodeFormats(ArrayList<BarcodeFormat> barcodeFormats)
        Set the format(s) of barcodes to be read.
        Parameters:
        barcodeFormats - An ArrayList of BarcodeFormats. Pass null or an empty ArrayList to disable barcode scanning. If you pass an non-empty ArrayList, scanning will be re-enabled.

      • getAvailableBarcodeFormats

        public ArrayList<BarcodeFormat> getAvailableBarcodeFormats()
        Get a list of all BarcodeFormats supported on the current device. This method only returns valid results, after the MeterReadingFragment was created and attached to an Activity. If no barcode reading is supported on this device, the list is empty.
        Returns:
        An ArrayList of all supported BarcodeFormats supported on the current device.

      • getBarcodeFormats

        Returns:

      • setRegionOfInterestInsets

        public boolean setRegionOfInterestInsets(Rect regionOfInterestInsets)
        Set region of interest insets to restrict meter reading to a specific area defined in absolute values.

        You can use this property to disallow processing at screen edges. As a general rule, you should set this property such that the space covered by user interface elements is not used for processing. For example, in order to spare out translucent areas covered by navigation bars etc..

        To create a dead area of 50 pixels on the left, 60 on the top, 50 on the right and 200 on the bottom, you can use this method as follows: setRegionOfInterestInsets(new Rect(50, 60, 50, 200));

        Parameters:
        regionOfInterestInsets - The insets in view coordinates to define a "dead area" where no processing shall be performed.
        Returns:
        False, when regionOfInterestInsets is larger than the view or insets are negative.
        See Also:
        setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets(android.graphics.RectF)

      • getRegionOfInterestInsets

        @Nonnull
public final Rect getRegionOfInterestInsets()
        Get the region of interest insets which restrict the meter reading to a specific area.
        Returns:
        The region of interest insets in view coordinates, defining a "dead area" where no processing shall be performed.

      • getRegionOfInterest

        @Nullable
public final Rect getRegionOfInterest()
        Get the region of interest which restricts the meter reading to a specific area.
        Returns:
        The region of interest in view coordinates, defining the area of the view in which processing shall be performed. May return `null` before the first layout of the views of the receiver.

      • setShowRegionOfInterest

        public void setShowRegionOfInterest(boolean showRegionOfInterest)
        Turn on or off the drawing of the region of interest.

        This includes drawing a border around the region of interest and filling the area outside of the region of interest.

        Parameters:
        showRegionOfInterest - Should the region of interest be drawn? Defaults to false.
        See Also:
        setRegionOfInterestInsets(Rect), setRegionOfInterestBorderColor(int), setRegionOfInterestBorderThickness(float), setRegionOfDisinterestFillColor(int)

      • getShowRegionOfInterest

        public boolean getShowRegionOfInterest()
        Return whether the border around the region of interest is drawn and the area outside of the region of interest is filled.
        Returns:
        true if the region of interest is drawn, false otherwise.

      • setRegionOfInterestBorderThickness

        public void setRegionOfInterestBorderThickness(float borderThickness)
        Set the width for the rectangle border's stroke around the region of interest.

        Pass 0 to stroke in hairline mode. Hairlines always draws a single pixel independent of the canvas' matrix.

        Parameters:
        borderThickness - The width of the border's stroke in DP.

      • getRegionOfInterestBorderThickness

        Returns:
        The width of the border's stroke in DP.

      • setRegionOfDisinterestFillColor

        public void setRegionOfDisinterestFillColor(int regionOfDisinterestFillColor)
        Set the color for the area outside the region of interest.

        You probably want to specify an alpha value for this color as well, e.g. like this: Color.argb(0x80, 0xC1, 0xDD, 0x4E).

        Parameters:
        regionOfDisinterestFillColor - Color for the area outside of the region of interest.

      • getRegionOfDisinterestFillColor

        Returns:
        Color for the area outside of the region of interest.

      • setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets

        public boolean setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets(RectF regionOfInterestInsets)
        Set region of interest insets to restrict meter reading to a specific area defined in relative values.

        You can use this property to disallow processing at screen edges. As a general rule, you should set this property such that the space covered by user interface elements is not used for processing. For example, in order to spare out translucent areas covered by navigation bars etc..

        To create a dead area of 10% on the left, 20% on the top, 15% on the right and 50% on the bottom, you can use this method as follows: setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets(new RectF(0.1f, 0.2f, 0.15f, 0.5f));

        Parameters:
        regionOfInterestInsets - The insets in the range of 0-1 to define a "dead area" where no processing shall be performed.
        Returns:
        False, when regionOfInterestInsets is larger than the view or insets are negative.
        See Also:
        setRegionOfInterestInsets(android.graphics.Rect)

      • setCounterBorderColor

        public void setCounterBorderColor(int borderColor)
        Set the color of the border around detected counters.
        Parameters:
        borderColor - The color for the border around detected counters. Defaults to Color.RED.

      • getCounterBorderColor

        public int getCounterBorderColor()
        Get the color of the border around detected counters.
        Returns:
        The color for the border around detected counters.

      • setCounterBorderThickness

        public void setCounterBorderThickness(float borderThickness)
        Set the width for the rectangle borders' stroke around detected counters.

        Pass 0 to stroke in hairline mode. Hairlines always draws a single pixel independent of the canvas' matrix.

        Parameters:
        borderThickness - The width of the borders' stroke in DP.

      • getCounterBorderThickness

        public float getCounterBorderThickness()
        Get the width for the rectangle borders' stroke around detected counters.
        Returns:
        The width of the borders' stroke in DP.

      • setBarcodeCaptureAnimation

        public void setBarcodeCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation barcodeCaptureAnimation)
        Set the MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful barcode reading.

        If you plan to verify detected barcode results in your implementation of the BarcodeReadingListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) method, you might want to decide when to show the capture animation. You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

        Default animation: MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.NONE

        Parameters:
        barcodeCaptureAnimation - The MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be performed whenever a new barcode was detected, i.e. when BarcodeReadingListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) is called.

      • setBarcodeCaptureAnimation

        @Deprecated

        Deprecated. Please use setBarcodeCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) instead.

        If you plan to verify detected barcode results in your implementation of the BarcodeReadingListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) method, you might want to decide when to show the capture animation. You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

        Default animation: MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation.NONE

        Set the MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful barcode reading.

        Parameters:
        barcodeCaptureAnimation - The MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation to be performed whenever a new barcode was detected, i.e. when BarcodeReadingListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) is called.

      • setMeterReadingCaptureAnimation

        public void setMeterReadingCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation meterReadingCaptureAnimation)
        Set the MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful meter reading.

        If you plan to verify meter reading results in your implementation of the MeterReadingListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) method, you might want to decide when to show the capture animation. You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

        Default animation: MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.FLASH

        Parameters:
        meterReadingCaptureAnimation - The MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be performed when a new meter reading was scanned, i.e. when MeterReadingListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) is called.

You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

        Default animation: MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation.FLASH

        Set the MeterReadingFragment.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful meter reading.

        Parameters:

      • hasTorch

        public boolean hasTorch()
        Return the presence of a torch/flashlight on the device.

        This method shall not be called before CameraListener.onCameraReady(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment) was called. (You may safely call it from your implementation of the onCameraViewCameraReady() callback.)

        Returns:
        true if the device has a torch; false otherwise.

      • isTorchOn

        public boolean isTorchOn()
        Return the current state of the device's torch/flashlight.

        This method shall not be called before CameraListener.onCameraReady(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment) was called. (You may safely call it from your implementation of the onCameraViewCameraReady() callback.)

        Returns:
        true if the torch is currently on; false otherwise. If the device does not have a torch, false is returned.

      • setTorchOn

        public void setTorchOn(boolean torchOn)
        Switch the device's torch/flashlight on or off. Invoking this method has no effect if the device does not have a torch.

        This method shall not be called before CameraListener.onCameraReady(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment)} was called. (You may safely call it from your implementation of the onCameraViewCameraReady() callback.)

        Parameters:
        torchOn - if true, the torch will be turned on; otherwise the torch will be turned off

      • initiateManualCapture

        public void initiateManualCapture()
        Initiate a capture of the next available image, even if no meter can be read.

        Invoke this method when you want to capture the image even if no counters could be found or read. Shortly after this method returns, your MeterReadingListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingFragment, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) callback will be invoked. (Note that it is possible that a counter could be successfully read after you invoke this method, so you should still inspect the results provided to your callback even if you previously initiated a manual capture using this method.)

      • isResultsOverlayVisible

        public boolean isResultsOverlayVisible()
        Return the visibility of an overlay that shows reading results.
        Returns:
        true if MeterReadingFragment displays results overlay; false otherwise. Defaults to true.

      • setResultsOverlayVisible

        public void setResultsOverlayVisible(boolean isResultsOverlayVisible)
        Set the visibility of an overlay that shows reading results. When the results overlay is shown it draws rectangular frames around detected counters, giving the user instant feedback that something is being read.

        You should not generally switch off the results overlay unless you provide your own visualization of detected counters.

        Parameters:
        isResultsOverlayVisible - A boolean value indicating whether to display a results overlay or not.

      • isDebugOverlayVisible

        public boolean isDebugOverlayVisible()
        Return the visibility of an overlay that shows debug information.

        The debug overlay is only drawn if the results overlay is also enabled (i.e. isResultsOverlayVisible() returns true).

        Returns:
        true if MeterReadingFragment displays an overlay with debug info. Defaults to false.

      • setDebugOverlayVisible

        public void setDebugOverlayVisible(boolean isDebugOverlayVisible)
        Set the visibility of an overlay that shows debug information.

        The debug overlay is only drawn if the results overlay is also enabled (i.e. isResultsOverlayVisible() returns true).

        The debug overlay is intended for debugging purposes in cooperation with pixolus. You should generally avoid enabling the debug overlay in production builds that are meant to be distributed to end users.

        Parameters:
        isDebugOverlayVisible - set to true if MeterReadingFragment should display an overlay with debug info

      • disableAutoFocus

        public boolean disableAutoFocus()
        Use this method to disable the autofocus operation. Disabling the autofocus can be useful for situations, where no meter reading should be performed but the user should be presented a camera preview. Do not forget to re-enable the autofocus afterwards using enableAutoFocus().
        Returns:
        True, when autofocus was disabled, false otherwise (e.g. when camera is not ready).

      • enableAutoFocus

        public boolean enableAutoFocus()
        Use this method to reenable the autofocus. After you have disabled the autofocus operation using disableAutoFocus() this method should be used to re-enable the autofocus.
        Returns:
        True, when autofocus was enabled, false otherwise (e.g. when camera is not ready).

      • onConfigurationChanged

        public void onConfigurationChanged(Configuration newConfig)
        Handle configuration changes of the device (e.g. orientation).

        Call this method from your Activity.onConfigurationChanged(android.content.res.Configuration) implementation when your hosting Activity handles configuration changes itself.

        If your Activity is restarted on device rotation, you can safely ignore this method.

        Specified by:
        onConfigurationChanged in interface ComponentCallbacks
        Overrides:
        onConfigurationChanged in class Fragment
        Parameters:
        newConfig - The new device Configuration.
